text.tspan: The frst step in creating a model is to describe relationships between variables. In Investi-
gation 1, we analyzed the relationship between Delbert’s sales and his income. Starting
from the verbal description of his income, we represented the relationship by a table of
values, a graph, and an algebraic equation. Each of these mathematical tools is useful in a
displays specifc data points with precise numerical values.
is a visual display of the data. It is easier to spot trends and describe the
overall behavior of the variables from a graph.
is a compact summary of the model. It can be used to analyze
the model and to make predictions.
We begin our study of modeling with some examples of
ples that follow, observe the interplay among the three modeling tools, and note how each
Annelise is on vacation at a seaside resort. She can rent a bicycle from her hotel for $3 an
hour, plus a $5 insurance fee. (Afraction of an hour is charged as the same fraction of $3.)
Make a table of values showing the cost,
, of renting a bike for various lengths of
Plot the points on a graph. Draw a curve through the data points.
To fnd the cost, multiply the time by $3 and add the result to the $5 insurance fee. For
example, the cost of a 1-hour bike ride is
A1-hour bike ride costs $8. Record the results in a table, as shown here:
Each pair of values represents a point on the graph. The frst value gives the horizontal
coordinate of the point, and the second value gives the vertical coordinate. The points
lie on a straight line, as shown in Figure 1.1. The line extends infnitely in only one
